Enrollment Protocol

How It Works (It Mostly Doesn't)

Our three-step process was designed by Dr. Meredith Blackpool (formerly "The Abyssal Surgeon") and has been described by the International Court of The Hague as "not technically illegal."

01

Crayon Intake Form

Complete the 47-page intake form using only the crayons provided. We accept Burnt Sienna, Midnight Betrayal, and our proprietary shade "Ethelred's Regret" (#3b0014). Pencil submissions are fed to the eels. No exceptions. The form asks standard questions: name, alias, number of active warrants, tentacle count (if applicable), and a 500-word essay titled "Why I Deserve Love Despite Everything."

02

The 72-Hour Evaluation

Conducted entirely through interpretive dance in a pressurized chamber at 340 meters depth. You will be assessed on emotional vulnerability, kraken compatibility, and your ability to express the concept of "trust" using only your left arm. Pass rate: 12%. Most failures occur during the "Betrayal Waltz" segment, which I personally choreographed and which I personally believe is fair.

03

Submersion & Matching

Your profile is carved into a basalt tablet and lowered into the Matching Trench (coordinates classified). Our algorithm — a blind octopus named Gerald who selects tablets by feel — has a 2.7% accuracy rate, which is higher than Tinder's. Gerald has been with us since 2018 and is the only employee who has never filed a complaint against me, personally.

Frequently Asked Questions

Answered personally by Ethelred Von Doom III, with increasing reluctance.

Because K3 confiscated my pens. All of them. Even the novelty one shaped like a swordfish that my grandfather gave me before the bouncy castle incident. They said it was a "security risk." A pen, Brenda. A pen shaped like a swordfish is not a security risk. It's a memento. So now everything is in crayon because that's what they left me with, and I have made it policy because if I have to suffer this indignity, so does everyone else. Next question.
Yes. Do you know how much it costs to maintain a submarine, feed an octopus a specialized diet of ethically sourced crab, pay off three separate maritime authorities, and keep an adequate supply of waterproof crayons? It's $498. The extra dollar is my salary. I make one dollar a month. I am not getting rich off this. I am barely getting fed off this. The $499 is fair and I will not be taking further questions on pricing. (There is a $299 "Shallow End" tier but it only grants you access to Gerald's rejected matches, which are mostly rocks and one very confused manatee.)
Define "success." If success means "two people met and did not immediately attempt to destroy each other," our rate is 34%. If success means "a lasting romantic connection," our rate is 2.7%. If success means "at least one party described the experience as 'not the worst thing that has ever happened to me,'" our rate is a very respectable 61%. I choose to focus on that last number. It's higher than K3's mixer, where the success rate for "not the worst thing" is 8%, primarily because of the oxygen tank situation, which they still refuse to address.
Gerald is a Giant Pacific Octopus, approximately 7 years old, and the most emotionally intelligent member of my staff (there are two of us). I found him in 2018 during what I will only describe as "a very bad night" involving a lost submarine, three expired flares, and a moment of genuine existential despair. Gerald approached my viewport and pressed one tentacle against the glass. I pressed my hand against it from the other side. We stayed like that for forty minutes. He's been with me since. His matching method — selecting basalt tablets by texture and weight — has no scientific basis whatsoever, but it has a higher accuracy rate than any dating algorithm on the surface, and more importantly, Gerald has never once suggested I attend a Sunshine & Sparkles mixer. He is my best friend. That is not relevant to this FAQ but I'm leaving it in.
This is a dating service FAQ, not a therapy session. Please restrict your questions to topics related to membership, pricing, depth clearance, or krakenology. I am fine. Gerald is fine. The submarine needs repairs but that's a funding issue, not an emotional one. I don't know why you'd ask that. I said I was fine. Please move on to the next question. There isn't one? Good. Fine. I'm going to go check on Gerald.
Ethelred's Corner

Administrator's Log

Entry dated: November 14, 2024 · Depth: 340m · Crayon: Midnight Betrayal

On the Subject of K3's Latest Outrage, and Why I Will Never Forgive Brenda

It has come to my attention that the Kiddie Krèche Kollective has launched their own "underwater dating experience," which they are calling — and I need you to sit down for this — "Splash of Love."

"Splash of Love." They're calling it "Splash of Love." As if the word "splash" has any place in serious underwater matchmaking. A splash is what happens at the surface. A splash is what children do in paddling pools. What we do at Abyssal Bonds happens at depth, where the pressure would crush a paddling pool into a disc the size of a postage stamp, along with any child foolish enough to be in it. (I am not threatening children. I am making a point about physics.)

[Editor's note: This section was originally four times longer. It has been trimmed for legal reasons. Ethelred's full remarks about Brenda, K3's activity coordinator, are available in the sealed archives. The phrase "bouncy castle apologist" appears seventeen times.]

K3's program is, predictably, a disaster. Their "matching system" involves a roulette wheel, a bag of gummy bears, and what Brenda describes as "vibes." Their first mixer resulted in three burst oxygen tanks (their signature move), one unplanned surfacing, and a 74-year-old retired doomsday architect sobbing into a pool noodle. That man was Reg. Reg came to me afterward. He didn't say anything. He just sat in my submarine for two hours, staring at Gerald.

I gave him a crayon and a piece of card stock. He drew a circle. I don't know what the circle meant. I didn't ask. That's the difference between Abyssal Bonds and K3. We don't ask about the circle. We just let you draw it.

Membership applications can be submitted via the crayon drop-box at Trench Marker 7. Please allow 14 weeks for processing. Gerald is doing his best.

— Ethelred Von Doom III, Founder & Sole Human Employee, Abyssal Bonds LLC (a submarine-based limited liability company, registered in no recognized jurisdiction)
